elements.name: Equity
elements.summary: Equity represents ownership in a company. The higher the equity stake, greater is the control over management of the company. Therefore, both founders and investors aim to secure (and retain) as much stake in the company as possible and avoid dilution./The word ‘equity’ also represents a type or class of shares issued by a company. Equity shares usually come attached with the rights to vote and receive dividends.

elements.name: Stock Options
elements.appearance: colorless gas, exhibiting a red-orange glow when placed in a high-voltage electric field
elements.summary: Stock options are ‘rights’ granted to employees to acquire the shares of the employer company at a fixed price (or strike price) against satisfaction of some conditions (vesting conditions). While the employee is not bound to exercise the stock options, the company will be bound to honour the grants as per its terms and conditions.

elements.name: CCPS
elements.summary: CCPS are compulsorily convertible preference shares. They provide investors the benefit of debt along with the economic risk of equity./CCPS convert to equity at predetermined time in future, or at the request of the shareholder, or if the conversion is linked to a future event (for example, a future round of financing or performance metrics agreed with the investor)./CCPS are often issued to non-resident investors.

elements.name: OCPS
elements.summary: Optionally convertible preference shares (OCPS) give their holders flexibility to either redeem the shares or convert to equity at a particular price. Typically, the redemption or conversion is linked to a certain date or event./Companies elect to raise funds by issuing OCPS, for flexibility in redeeming shares and returning funds, thus avoiding dilution of ownership for existing shareholders. Investors like to keep the option to convert to equity, and benefit from the increase in valuation of the company over the period of OCPS.

elements.name: Option Plan
elements.summary: ESOP or employee stock option plan – is an employee incentive (benefit) plan intended to encourage employees to acquire ownership in the company. Stock options allow employees to purchase the company’s shares in the future at a fixed (usually discounted) price. This means employees can convert their options to shares at a price lower than the existing value of shares, the difference being the reward for the employees./Stock option plans motivate employees to perform better,  promote incentive-based compensation, align employee interests with the company vision and growth, thus creating value for both company and employees.

elements.name: Option Pool
elements.summary: Companies create and reserve a percentage of their stock for issue to their employees in future. A stock option pool consists of shares reserved for issue to employees based on a board-approved plan./Since creating the pool has a dilutionary impact on all shareholders, new investors normally insist on the stock option pool being created prior to their investment, or on a pre-money basis./Typically, the ESOP pool varies between 5% and 20% of the issued capital on a fully diluted basis. As companies grow and more employees are hired, this percentage could increase.

elements.name: SAR (Phantom)
elements.summary: SAR refers to stock appreciation rights./It is an employee incentive arrangement (a variation of the stock option plan) in which employees are paid an amount equivalent to the appreciated value of stock of the company. The appreciated value is the difference between the price of shares between the grant date and exercise date of the SAR./A SAR is normally paid in cash, although it could also be settled in equivalent value of stock. Alternatively, a SAR could also be settled in a combination of cash and stock./SARs do not represent actual equity – employees only enjoy the economic benefit of appreciation in the value of a specified number of shares that the company committed when the SARs were granted to the employee.

elements.name: ESPP
elements.summary: ESPP refers to employee stock purchase plan./Under this plan, employees receive the right to purchase the shares of a public listed company at a discounted value. This option is available only if the shares have been listed on a recognised stock exchange. An agreed percentage of the employee’s salary is deducted over a period of time, which is then aggregated and used to buy the company’s stock on scheduled dates in future.

elements.name: Employee Trust
elements.summary: Companies can issue stock options using various plans (employee stock option plans / ESOP). Under the trust plan, the legal ownership of shares is granted to a trust created specifically for this purpose, which will then issue shares to employees of the company./The Trust acts as an intermediary between the company and employees to implement the ESOP./Employees who are issued stock options under this plan are granted all the economic benefits of ownership of shares although legal ownership remains with the trust.

elements.name: MSOP
elements.appearance: colorless gas exhibiting an orange-red glow when placed in a high voltage electric field
elements.summary: MSOP refers to ‘management stock option plan’. Some companies formulate a stock ownership plan exclusively for a company’s senior management executives and executive board members based on their performance or tenure with the company./MSOP is typically rolled out with a pre-vesting schedule and vesting period. The board of directors of the company executes the MSOP

elements.name: Convertible Note
elements.summary: Convertible notes are short-term financing instruments that are issued when the company wants to raise an interim round of financing. They are issued with an option for conversion to equity in the future. Usually, notes convert to equity based on a trigger event. This could be a future round of financing, operation metrics, pure passage of time or at the discretion of the company./Typically, the terms of issue of convertible notes cover aspects such as:/a. Details of conversion parameters/b. Rate of interest and type/c. Term (duration) of note/d. Terms of repayment/e. Discount on valuation during conversion/f. Cap on valuation during conversion

elements.name: SAFE
elements.summary: SAFE is an instrument that allows a company to issue shares to an investor for money invested on the occurrence of a predetermined trigger event./Most startups need to raise money soon after formation to fund operations. Unlike traditional priced rounds, a company can issue a SAFE quickly and efficiently, without multiple documents.  It’s a flexible, one-document security, without numerous terms to negotiate, saving companies and investors money and time./Here, the investor and company agree on a cap on valuation, sign and date a SAFE, and the investor sends the company the investment amount. An outstanding SAFE is present on the company’s cap table, like any other convertible security (such as a warrant or an option).

elements.name: Grant
elements.summary: Awarding stock options to employees is called a ‘grant’. All the terms of the grant must be captured in the grant letter, such as the number of options being granted, cliff period, grant date, grant price, vesting period, vesting conditions, exercise price, exercise period, tax implications, restrictions on transfer, and so on.

elements.name: Vesting
elements.summary: Vesting is a process by which an employee, who has been granted stock options in their company, earns the right to purchase the shares. An employee becomes eligible to exercise her options only when all the vesting conditions as specified in the grant letter have been met. These vesting conditions may be linked to time, performance, or an event.

elements.name: Vesting Schedule
elements.appearance: colourless, waxy white, yellow, scarlet, red, violet, black
elements.summary: A schedule with conditions that determines when stock options granted to employees will vest./The conditions can be based on time, performance, or an event. In time-based vesting, options vest simply with the passage of time, i.e., as long as an employee continues in employment. In performance-based vesting, conditions mandate the employee to achieve certain targets for options to vest. In event-based vesting, vesting will depend on the occurrence of certain events, such as the company being listed for public trading, or becoming a unicorn, or becoming profitable.

elements.name: Strike Price
elements.summary: The price at which the options are bought./There are two broad models for this./Model 1 is the par value of the share. This does not apply in legal terms in the case of Phantom grants. Phantom grants have a nil Strike Price./Model 2 is linking the strike price to the fair value of the shares at the time the grant is made. The discount may range from 0% to whatever the company determines. 25% to 40% would be a good number. It works well both for the employee and the company./Companies may grant a lower number of Options in Model 1 or a higher number of Options in Model 2. In Model 1, the employee has a higher chance of making a return. This becomes fairly attractive in late stage companies because the employee knows that there is a high likelihood of making something out of the Options. In Model 2, if the company does well, the employee may actually make a much higher return.

elements.name: Exercise
elements.summary: In the context of an employee stock option plan (ESOP), ‘exercise’ refers to the act of exercising one’s right to purchase the shares of the company where one is an employee./When an employee fulfills the vesting conditions stipulated in the ESOP, the options ‘vest’ and they can convert the options to shares by exercising their right to buy the shares. Once options are exercised, the employee becomes a shareholder in the company./All options come with an exercise period within which the employee must exercise their right. Once the options vest, the option holder may at any time during the exercise period submit an application (exercise letter) to the board of directors, for allotment of shares. If options are not exercised during the exercise period, they automatically lapse.

elements.name: Exercise Period
elements.appearance: colorless gas exhibiting a lilac/violet glow when placed in a high voltage electric field
elements.summary: Employees earn the right to exercise options granted to them by fulfilling the conditions stated in the ESOP plan and or grant letter. Once the options vest, employees exercise their right to purchase the shares of the company within the stipulated duration mentioned in the grant letter. This is the exercise period. Failure to exercise before the exercise window closes will mean that the options lapse.

elements.name: CCD
elements.summary: CCD means compulsorily convertible debenture. It is a hybrid security, which converts to equity after a given period./Holders of CCDs receive interest on the debt component of the instrument, with the added advantage of equity on conversion. Interest is paid quarterly, half yearly, or yearly, as per the terms of the investment agreement./Holders of CCDs will be included in the company’s cap table only when the security actually converts to equity.

elements.name: NCD
elements.summary: Non-convertible debenture (NCD) is a debt instrument that does not carry an option to convert to equity. They are securities issued by a debtor company, to acknowledge debt. NCD holders receive interest for a fixed duration. Companies issue NCDs if they want to raise capital without the need to issue equity, avoiding dilution for existing shareholders./1. Secured NCDs – NCDs are backed by the company's assets. If the company fails to make the payment on time, investors can recover their investment by liquidating the security./2. Unsecured NCDs –  no assets back up the loan. If the debtor company defaults, investors must wait until the company recovers and can pay back the principal amount. The advantage for holders however is that because of the higher risk, unsecured NCDs carry higher interest rates.

elements.name: Term Sheet
elements.summary: A term sheet is a non-binding commitment usually (though not always) between/(a) an investor and /(b) a company./The term sheet sets out basic terms of the proposed transaction, and these rights and obligations are elaborated in the shareholders’ agreement./The term sheet covers company value, investment amount, type of security, governance of company, and investor exit.

elements.name: SHA
elements.summary: SHA means shareholders’ agreement./It is a binding contract between the parties to the investment deal – founders, investors, and company. The shareholders’ agreement includes clauses on rights of shareholders (anti-dilution, transfer of share, exit, liquidation preference, etc.) and management of company (voting rights, reserved matters, etc.)/A well-drafted shareholders’ agreement brings clarity for the parties and ensures smooth management of a company’s affairs.

elements.name: SSA
elements.summary: SSA means share subscription agreement./It is executed between a company and an investor. The company commits to issue a certain number of shares to the investor, who commits to invest a certain amount. The company’s founders also sign the share subscription agreement, which also contains details of conditions to be satisfied before investment is completed, and information about the number of shares and terms of their issue.

elements.name: AOA
elements.summary: A company’s articles of association are a comprehensive set of rules and regulations that govern its management and regulate the relationship between its shareholders./Provisions of agreements which define rights and obligations of shareholders (founders, investors, etc.) must be incorporated in the articles for them to be valid and enforceable./A company’s articles of association need to be filed with the Registrar of Companies (under the Ministry of Corporate Affairs) at the time of its incorporation./A company may modify its articles through a special resolution passed  in a shareholders’ meeting.

elements.name: MOA
elements.summary: Memorandum of Association (MOA) is a charter document of the company. It specifies activities that the company will undertake. The MOA contains details of a company’s name, its registered address, objectives, authorised capital, liability of the members, and the subscribers. All activities of the company must always be conducted within the operational scope defined in the memorandum./Any changes to the clauses of the memorandum must be approved by the board of directors and the shareholders. To alter the memorandum, the company must:/1. Hold a board meeting seeking approval/2. Call an extraordinary general meeting seeking approval from shareholders/After the shareholders approve, the special resolution passed must be filed with the ROC in form MGT-14.

elements.name: Pre Money
elements.appearance: lustrous metallic with a grayish tinge
elements.summary: Pre-money valuation is the value of the company as agreed by the investor and the company prior to a new round of financing investment./This value is determined based on various factors such as the company’s nature of business, revenue growth, sales, competitors, market share, etc.

elements.name: Post Money
elements.summary: The value of the company after a new round of financing is called the post-money valuation of the company./Post-money valuation is the pre-money value of the company together with the investment amount received in the new round.

elements.name: Dilution
elements.appearance: lustrous, metallic, and silver with a gold tinge
elements.summary: When a company issues new shares to new investors, the shareholding percentage of existing shareholders reduces - this is called dilution of their shareholding./Every time shares are issued to a new investor, the shareholding of existing shareholders dilutes, even if they participate in the new round./Essentially, although the pie increases (more shares issued), because there are more takers (incoming investor), the number of slices increases (investor + existing shareholders) while the size of the slice reduces for each of them.

elements.name: LP
elements.summary: When a company goes into liquidation, holders of preference shares are entitled to receive the amount of capital they invested. The liquidation preference clause specifies when and how much of the capital will be returned to shareholders in the event of liquidation./Standard terms are ‘Rank’ and ‘Participation’./Rank decides the order in which the capital is returned to investors. Holders of preference shares are always ranked ahead of equity shareholders./Participation decides the amount of proceeds from liquidation payable to investors. This could be an amount equal to investment (1x), twice the amount (2x), and so on.

elements.name: Anti Dilution
elements.summary: Anti-dilution or valuation protection rights is a protection given to the shareholders of the company to protect them from the down round./In any future round, if the company issues shares at a price lesser than the price originally paid by the investors in the previous round for the same class of shares, it results in a dilutive issuance of additional equity shares to the new investors which is unfair to the existing shareholders. Accordingly, in a down-round, the existing investors benefit in the form of an increased ownership in the company, by way of an adjustment to the conversion price or conversion ratio of the convertible securities held by them.

elements.name: Founder Vesting
elements.summary: Founder vesting is the process by which the founder earns the right to purchase the shares depending on your performance and commitment to the startup. It is similar to stock-options vesting. The founder becomes eligible to exercise options only when all the vesting conditions have been met./The founders vesting is ideally captured in the founders agreement.

elements.name: Lock In
elements.summary: Lock-in period usually refers to a duration when certain actions are restricted. In the context of start-ups and founders’ commitments to investors, it’s seen that investors usually insist that the ability of founders to sell their shareholding in the company is restricted for a specified duration. With each new round of funding, however, founders can request for a higher amount of liquidity. Later-stage investors are often more comfortable providing liquidity to founders.

elements.name: Cliff
elements.summary: Cliff is the time frame during which no vesting of options takes place. Under Indian law, the minimum cliff period is one year./A cliff restricts the employees from leaving the company with shares after having worked for only a few months. Options granted without cliff puts the company at a disadvantage because the replacement hired may also need to be compensated with stock options.

elements.name: Acceleration
elements.appearance: black, red, and gray (not pictured) allotropes
elements.summary: Employee stock option plans contain vesting schedules, which specify when options vest in favour of the holder (usually an employee). Once vested, the holder exercises the option (right) to purchase shares in the company, thus becoming a shareholder./A vesting schedule has milestones based on time or performance. Vesting usually follows the schedule without deviation./Sometimes however, vesting can be speeded up. This is ‘acceleration’ of vesting. When this happens, the schedule is bypassed and options vest even before the vesting period expires or the performance milestone is reached and option holders become shareholders earlier than agreed./Events that typically lead to acceleration of vesting – called triggers – are when the company is set to be listed on the stock exchange (IPO) or be sold or merged into another company (acquisition or merger), or a part of the company is being hived off (demerger). These are events in a company’s life that change its ownership, which can mean new conditions of employment (including vesting), with the possibility of employees being let go or opting to leave without being compensated as they expected, that is, share ownership./Acceleration of vesting (or accelerated vesting) prevents such consequences, and a portion (or whole) of the options will immediately vest.

elements.name: Single Trigger
elements.summary: If the vesting of stock options accelerates based on the occurrence of a single event or a single factor, it is called a single trigger.

elements.name: Double Trigger
elements.appearance: colorless gas, exhibiting a whitish glow in a high electric field
elements.summary: When more than one event results in acceleration of vesting an employee’s stock options, the events are called a double trigger./Examples include termination of employees as a result of the company being acquired or because of a change in the ownership of the company.

elements.name: Warrant
elements.summary: Warrants are a type of convertible security that give their holders the right to purchase the underlying security at the price determined at the time of entering into the investment deal./There is no obligation on the investor to exercise the warrant and buy the underlying stock.

elements.name: Partly Paid Shares
elements.summary: Shares issued by a company against which shareholders have only made partial payment are called partially paid shares./Some aspects affected by partly paid shares are:/1. Issue of bonus shares: A company cannot issue bonus shares unless shares are fully paid up./2. Transfer of partly paid shares: A company has to notify the transferee of partial payment and obtain a no objection certificate to record the transfer of such shares./3. Conversion: Convertible shares can be converted to equity only when they are fully paid up.

elements.name: Drag Along
elements.summary: A contractual right of one (or some) shareholders to convince all other shareholders to sell their equity to a third party on the same terms as the sale of their shareholding. This helps protect the interests of all shareholders so they can enjoy the benefits of higher return on their sale. It’s also called the ‘bring along’ right./Usually, majority shareholders have a drag-along right. However, it is often seen that VC and PE investors - even when they have a minority shareholding - have a contractual right to drag the founders and other shareholders along in a sale negotiated by the investors. However, the drag along right is available only under certain conditions - for example, if investors have not got an exit at the end of an agreed duration and remain shareholders, or if the company or founders have committed fraud or a substantial breach of agreements./In an event of the drag sale, the founders and other shareholders shall be required to sell their shares on the same terms and price as those determined by investors.

elements.name: Tag Along
elements.summary: A contractual right given to minority shareholders (usually, financial investors in a start-up), allowing them to sell a portion of their shares to the buyer who has offered to buy shares from the majority shareholders of a company (usually, the founders in a start-up), on the same purchase terms offered to the majority./For more details, see the item titled ‘Co-sale right’.

elements.name: ROFR
elements.summary: ROFR means ‘right of first refusal’./The right given to shareholders in a company to purchase the shares being sold by other shareholders in the same company. ROFR casts an obligation on the selling shareholders to first offer the shares they wish to sell to ROFR holders./For instance, if a founder wishes to transfer their shares, other shareholders (founders and or investors) will have a right to purchase all or part of such shares, at the same price and terms being offered by a third party buyer (if any)./However, if the shareholders with the ROFR do not exercise it, the selling shareholders can transfer the shares to a third party.

elements.name: ROFO
elements.summary: ROFO means ‘right of first offer’./The right given to shareholders in a company to purchase shares being sold by other shareholders in the same company./For instance, if a founder wishes to transfer their shares, other shareholders (founders and or investors) will have a right to first offer to purchase all or part of such shares./However, the selling shareholder can still transfer such shares to a third party, if the price quoted by them is higher than the price offered by current shareholders.

elements.name: Co-Sale
elements.summary: A contractual right given to minority shareholders (usually, financial investors in a start-up), allowing them to sell a portion of their shares to the buyer who has offered to buy shares from the majority shareholders of a company (usually, the founders in a start-up), on the same purchase terms offered to the majority./This right is also called the right to ‘tag along’. It’s a provision that protects the rights of minority shareholders and gives them liquidity./Terms and conditions of how and when the right can be exercised are detailed in shareholders’ agreements and or the Articles of Association of the company.

elements.name: Affirmative Votes
elements.summary: Investors need to protect the funds they have invested in a company. To do so, they need to exercise some control over its activities, especially if they involve  expansion of operations, capital expenditure, change in ownership, new investments, or changes to business plans./In shareholders’ agreements, which investors sign with the company and its founders, there are clauses which restrict management from taking certain business and operational decisions unless the investors vote in their  favour.  These are called the investors’ ‘affirmative voting rights’, which can be exercised in board or shareholders’ meetings. These protect investors and prevent any management action that could be detrimental to their interests./Affirmative voting rights are important because investors are usually minority shareholders in a company and the majority has the shareholding percentage to push through certain decisions despite the investors’ objections. So, a contractual obligation to get the investors’ affirmative votes on certain ‘reserved matters’ is needed./These rights, also called ‘veto rights’, are typically exercised in critical matters such as amendments to a company’s charter documents, declaration of dividend, issue of new shares, appointment and removal of auditors, change of company’s name or registered office, disposal of company’s assets, investments in other entities, capital expenditure, acquisition of other businesses, transfer of business, company’s dissolution, corporate restructuring, and so on.

elements.name: Pari Passu
elements.summary: Every security issued to investors comes with its own set of terms, which provide its holders certain rights. This can be in relation to dividend rates, voting rights, liquidation preference, etc./The pari passu clause, when applied, makes it mandatory that all holders of a specific security must be treated on the same footing as equity shareholders./For example, pari passu dividend rights means that holders of non-equity shares of the company receive the same dividend as equity shareholders.

elements.name: Pro-rata
elements.summary: Pro rata means proportionate. It is a common term used in several investment documents. Pro rata can be applied to several contexts./For example, when companies raise additional funds by issuing shares, the existing investor can subscribe to additional shares in the new round in proportion to their current shareholding (pro rata), calculated on a fully diluted basis.

elements.name: Full Ratchet
elements.summary: Full ratchet is an anti-dilution method that protects the shareholders from dilution of their equity resulting from a future round of financing at a lower valuation./If a company issues stock in the new round at a price lower than the price originally paid by the shareholder for the same class of stock, the existing shareholders can subscribe to the shares at the lower share price and prevent dilution of their ownership. Here, the conversion price is adjusted down to match the issuance price of shares in the new round.

elements.name: Weighted Average
elements.summary: Weighted average is a calculation used for anti-dilution protection, when a down round occurs. It is used to adjust the value of the preference shares of existing shareholders to a new weighted average price, which will be the conversion price./Common weighted average calculation methods are:/ (a) broad- based weighted average and/ (b) narrow- based weighted average./In the broad-based weighted average method, all the outstanding (issued) shares, including convertible instruments (presumed to have been converted to equity) are considered on a fully diluted basis, whereas in the narrow-based weighted average method, only equity and preference shares that convert to equity are considered.

elements.name: FMV
elements.summary: Fair market value refers to the price at which an asset, property, or business would be sold in the open market. The following conditions are also important in arriving at the fair market value: both the buyer and seller are acting in their own interest, without pressure, with the freedom to decide and mutually agree on price, have knowledge of relevant facts and a reasonable time to complete the transaction./In case of shares or securities of a company, fair market value refers to their value (price) in the market.

elements.name: In the Money
elements.summary: ‘In the money’ refers to an option that can be exercised by paying a price (strike price) lower than the current prevailing price of the option in the market. The option holder owns an asset (share) worth more than what they paid.

elements.name: Capital Gains
elements.summary: Capital gain is an increase in the value of an asset, which when it is sold by the owner, creates income. The asset could be tangible, such as a house, car, building site, or intangible, such as shares, bonds, or other securities./Capital gain can be short-term (less than a year) or long-term (more than a year). Capital gains are usually taxed as income tax. The difference between the actual sale price and the cost of acquisition of the asset is taxed as capital gain. Long-term capital gain is taxed at a lower rate than short-term capital gains usually./On the other hand, if the holder of an asset makes a loss when the asset is sold, the loss can be carried forward to the following financial years, and set off against any gain that occurs in future.

elements.name: Spread
elements.summary: The difference between the bid price and the ask price of options is called the spread.

elements.name: Reverse Vesting
elements.appearance: lustrous metallic gray, violet as a gas
elements.summary: Since the growth of a company depends substantially on its founders, especially in the initial stages, many early-stage investors ask that the founders surrender some or all of their shares if they leave the company within a certain period, whatever the reason for exit. The surrendered shares are usually redistributed amongst the remaining founders or offered to incoming management personnel. This is called reverse vesting./The objective of reverse vesting is to prevent unnecessary dilution and to avoid rewarding an exiting founder. If a founder leaves, their replacement will need to be incentivised through options. This will result in a dilution of other shareholders’ stake, which can be avoided by transferring the exiting founder’s shares to them.

elements.name: Restricted Stock
elements.appearance: colorless gas, exhibiting a blue glow when placed in a high voltage electric field
elements.summary: Restricted stock units (RSUs) are a type of employee incentive where a certain number of shares vest with the employee in future, provided that employee fulfills certain conditions, for ex. satisfaction of specific performance goals or continuing to work with the company for a certain duration./Once the employee meets these conditions, the employee earns shares or their cash equivalent.

elements.name: FDB
elements.summary: FDB refers to ‘fully diluted basis’. It is the term used to describe a condition in which all shares considered to be issued, securities and convertible instruments are converted, options are exercised, and all of them have converted to equity shares. This assumption helps in determining the true percentage of holding of each shareholder, whether founder, angel, or investor./Using the FDB concept, the precise holding of each shareholder is calculated, by dividing the number of shares each shareholder owns by the total shares issued by the company. Shares issued include equity shares and dilutive instruments including stock options issued reserved, assuming that they have been exercised or converted to equity./As a term, FDB is most often used in shareholders agreements, share subscription agreements, and term sheets. It gives the true shareholding percentage of an investor, and helps in understanding pre-money, post-money, and dilutive percentages of shareholding before and after every round of financing.

elements.name: PAR
elements.summary: The founders decide the par value of stock at the time of incorporation. The par value is mentioned in the company’s charter documents.

elements.name: Secondaries
elements.summary: The secondary transaction or sale of shares is when an existing shareholder of the company sells their shares to another shareholder or private investor or back to the company for a negotiated consideration. Under the secondary transaction of shares, no new shares are issued by the company. Secondary transactions involve two parties-/ (i) the seller who can be the employees, promoters or other shareholders; and/ (ii) the buyer who can be other shareholders, investors, the company etc. Secondary transactions do not result in any change in the capital of the company. Here, only the ownership of shares changes hands while the total number of shares the company has issued remains the same. It is only the shareholders selling their shares who receive the benefit of the transaction.

elements.name: Venture Debt
elements.summary: Venture debt is a type of debt financing for early-stage companies or start-ups that have venture backing - it can be complementary to raising funds from equity financing. Funds can be raised from banks or non-bank lenders. Venture debt allows start-ups to raise capital by avoiding or postponing dilution, especially between two rounds of funding./Unlike conventional debt, venture debt does not necessarily require collateral (since start-ups do not generally own any assets that can be used as such) or positive cash flows. But the cost of venture debt is higher than regular debt./Usually, venture debt carries a regular interest payment, requires a fee to be paid to process the loan, as well as issuing warrants to venture debt providers

elements.name: Buy Back
elements.summary: A company purchasing its own stock is called buy back./Most often, companies buy back shares:/a. To decrease the number of outstanding shares in the hands of investors. To increase promoters’ shareholding (since shares bought back are cancelled)/b. To increase earnings per share (if a company’s earnings are the same, buy back of shares reduces the number of shares issued)/c. To pay surplus cash to shareholders when the company does not need it for its business/d. To reward shareholders by buying back of shares at a substantially higher price than market price/e. To support share price on stock exchanges if company management thinks that the share price is less than its worth/There is a limit to how many shares can be bought back during a financial year, and only a company with sufficient cash (in free reserves or in its securities premium account)  can do so.

elements.name: Change in Control
elements.summary: A change in control occurs when the majority of shares in the company changes hands. Since shares represent ownership and owners have control over the affairs of the company, a change in ownership leads to a change in control. This typically happens when another party acquires more than 50% of the company’s ownership.

elements.name: DVR
elements.summary: Equity shares can be ordinary shares or have differential voting rights, which give its holders different rights to vote, receive dividends, etc., compared to the rights of ordinary shareholders./Amendments to the Companies Act have  allowed companies to issue shares with different voting and dividend rights, in contrast to the earlier restriction on issuing shares that allow its holder only one vote for every share held or proportionate to their share in the paid up capital of the company./The Articles of Association of the company must contain the clause that allows the company to issue shares with DVR.

elements.name: Reserved Matter
elements.summary: Investors need to protect the funds they have invested in a company. To do so, they need to exercise some control over its activities. This is why there are clauses in the shareholders agreement  which restrict management from taking certain business and operational decisions, unless the investors vote in their  favour.  These are called the investors’ ‘affirmative voting rights’. These protect investors and prevent any management action./Affirmative voting rights are important because investors are usually minority shareholders in a company and the majority has the shareholding percentage to push through certain decisions despite the investors’ objections. So, a contractual obligation to get the investors’ affirmative votes on certain ‘reserved matters’ is needed./These rights, also called ‘veto rights’, are typically exercised in critical matters such as amendments to a company’s charter documents, issue of new shares, appointment and removal of auditors, change of company’s name or registered office, disposal of company’s assets, investments in other entities, capital expenditure, acquisition of other businesses, company’s dissolution, corporate restructuring, and so on.

elements.name: Veto Rights
elements.summary: A contractual right given to some shareholders (usually financial investors who have a minority stake) to override decisions taken by the majority (in shareholders’ meetings) or company management (in board meetings) is called a ‘veto’. A list of ‘reserved matters’ is usually agreed in writing, in which consent of minority shareholders is essential and in such matters, they can exercise their veto rights./For more details, see item titled ‘Affirmative votes’.

elements.name: Information Rights
elements.summary: To protect their investment, investors usually want the right to receive certain specific and detailed information from the company on a regular basis, such as key performance metrics, MIS, any significant events, etc./Investors also want to be able to carry out inspections, review documents and records, talk to vendors, employees, counsel, auditors etc., if they suspect any foul play of any kind. These are information and inspection rights that are usually negotiated and agreed in shareholders’ agreements./Although as shareholders they have certain rights under the law, they seek additional information for greater protection.

elements.name: Conditions Precedent
elements.summary: Before an investment or acquisition transaction can be closed, the investor or acquirer asks the company (or sellers) to satisfy various conditions. While some conditions relate to corporate actions to approve the investment or acquisition, others involve actions to be taken to remedy non-compliance identified during the due diligence process./After the conditions are satisfied, the company’s directors (or sellers) must sign a certificate stating that all the necessary actions have been taken and formalities completed.

elements.name: CS
elements.summary: The process of fundraising does not end when the company receives the investment amount. The company has to also fulfil certain other conditions afterwards, which are usually timebound. . These could be filing statutory forms (PAS-3 and MGT-14), obtaining insurance to protect directors from liability, re-signing contracts with vendors or clients, preparing and implementing stock option plans, and so on./After the conditions are satisfied, the company and the founders must confirm this to the investor in writing.

elements.name: Dividend
elements.summary: Dividend is return on equity investment, that is, distribution of profits of a company amongst equity investors./Since dividends take away a chunk of cash from the company, companies usually pay dividends at a nominal rate (0.001% or 0.0001%).  A higher rate of dividend usually is cumulative and negotiated as part of the term sheet with investors./Different classes of shares may also be entitled to different dividend payouts. This is also usually negotiated and contracted as part of term sheets agreements.

elements.name: Premium
elements.summary: When the shares of a company are issued at a price that is higher than the par value, the amount exceeding the par value is called the premium./For example, if the par value of a company’s shares is INR 10 and new shares are issued at INR 15 per share, INR 5 is the premium.

elements.name: Authorized Capital
elements.summary: The maximum amount of capital that a company can raise by issuing shares is called its authorised share capital./A company’s authorised capital is specified in its Memorandum of Association (MOA) (in the capital clause)./If the company wants to increase the authorised capital, the MOA must be amended by passing an ordinary resolution in a meeting of the company’s shareholders.

elements.name: Paid-up Capital
elements.summary: The amount of money paid by shareholders of a company for shares issued to them is called paid-up share capital./This amount represents the company’s actual capital, and is not money borrowed./The paid-up capital has a bearing on several aspects:/1. Calculating the equity holding of shareholders, their voting rights, and payment of dividend/2. Buyback of shares/3. Bonus issue  of shares/4. Call on shares, if some shares are partly paid-up/5. Alteration of capital/6. Additional issue of capital

elements.name: Subscribed Capital
elements.summary: A portion of capital that has been subscribed by investors, that is, investors have expressed interest in buying shares of that company./‘Oversubscribed’ means that the company has received applications for more shares than it has offered for sale./‘Undersubscribed’ means that the company has received applications for fewer shares than those offered for sale.

elements.name: Valuation Report
elements.summary: Various corporate actions require a company to be valued. For instance, the Companies Act, 2013 mandates valuation by a registered valuer in the case of a new issue of shares, mergers and amalgamations or debt restructuring. Likewise, the FDI guidelines under FEMA  provide for valuation if shares are issued by an unlisted company to a non-resident investor./Registered valuers are appointed to work out an estimated value of the company. Various factors, such as the company’s growth rate, financials, market, competitors, and nature of the business, are considered to determine the value./The findings of the valuer and supporting information assessed by the valuer are disclosed in a valuation report.

elements.name: RV
elements.summary: Registered valuers are professionals who determine the value of a company based on various factors, such as the company’s growth rate, financials, competitors, nature of business, and market.. Registered valuers are typically appointed by the company with the consent of investors./Findings of the registered valuer are disclosed in a certified valuation report.

elements.name: MB
elements.summary: Merchant banks are institutions that provide loans, undertake portfolio management, underwriting services, and advisory services. They act as intermediaries between investors and companies and assist their clients in trading shares on the stock exchange.

elements.name: Private Placement
elements.summary: Private placement is the offer of securities to a selected group of persons other than by public offer. The offer is made through a private placement letter. The offer letter for subscription (in Form PAS-4) is sent to a maximum of 50 selected individuals excluding the employees of the company and qualified institutional buyers. All details of the private placement are maintained in Form PAS-5./A few key points to note are:/1. A separate bank account has to be maintained to deal with the subscription money received towards private placement and other related transactions./2. Investors can subscribe to shares only through cheque, demand drafts, or other banking channels, and not through cash.

elements.name: Rights Issue
elements.summary: Rights issue refers to an invitation to existing shareholders of a company to subscribe to new or additional shares being issued, usually in proportion to their existing holding of shares in order to maintain their shareholding percentage.

elements.name: Bonus Issue
elements.summary: When additional shares are issued to a company’s shareholders, free of cost, it’s called a bonus issue. Shares are issued from the accumulated profits of the company in proportion to the shares held by shareholders as on date./Companies issue bonus shares to encourage retail participation and increase their equity base. When the price per share of a company is high, it becomes difficult for new investors to buy  them. Bonus shares increase the number of shares and lower the price per share. This provides liquidity to shareholders. The overall capital remains the same however even when bonus shares are declared./Sometimes, companies also issue bonus shares when they are not able to pay dividends due to shortage of funds.

elements.name: Stock Split
elements.summary: A unit of the company's stock broken into multiple sub-units of smaller denomination is a stock split./Split does not result in the percentage shareholding of the investor changing. However, the number of shares that the shareholder holds post split goes up.

elements.name: Demat
elements.summary: Holding securities (shares, debentures, bonds, or government securities) in digital/electronic or dematerialised form is called ‘demat’./If an investor wishes to purchase securities in the demat form, the seller has to give instruction to the registered Depository Participant to debit his/her account and credit the purchaser/beneficiary owner account. The beneficiary owner then directs the depository participant to receive credit of the securities./Shareholders wishing to sell the securities, should give a delivery instruction to the Depository Participant to debit his/her account and credit the purchaser’s account. These instructions have to be given to the Depository Participant at least 24 hours before receiving the payment against such sale.

elements.name: Depository
elements.summary: Depository is a body that holds securities of investors in electronic (demat) form. This includes shares, debentures, bonds, or government securities./Under the depository system of holding shares, a depository entity registered with SEBI holds securities of various companies for investors in demat form. Any transaction involving securities is completed through the depository. Currently, NSDL and CDSL are the main depositories in India./Depositories appoint depository participants who are middlemen between themselves and investors. Banks, share transfer agents, and financial institutions authorised by SEBI are depository participants. All communications between investors and depositories are through depository participants.

elements.name: EGM
elements.summary: EGM refers to an extraordinary general meeting. Any meeting of the shareholders of a company, other than the annual general meeting (AGM), is called an EGM./An EGM is usually called to discuss matters such as:/a. Removal of a director or auditor/b. Modification to articles of association/c. Issue of shares or other securities/d. Important business or legal concerns that need shareholders’ approval/To call an EGM, the board of directors of a company must send a notice to shareholders, indicating the date and time, along with a detailed agenda. The notice must be accompanied by a resolution passed by the board calling the EGM and recording reasons for calling it.

elements.name: AGM
elements.summary: Every company (other than a one-person company) must hold a general meeting of the company’s shareholders every year. Prior notice of at least 21 days must be given before the AGM is conducted./In an AGM, financial statements for the previous year are presented, directors are appointed to the board, statutory auditors are appointed, compensation for top executives is decided, and dividends are declared.

elements.name: Director
elements.summary: A director is an individual appointed at the time of incorporation of a company or by its board to manage both its strategic activities and day-to-day operations./A director must fulfill the roles and responsibilities assigned to them by the board from time to time./Any individual, regardless of nationality (except those belonging to certain countries) and in possession of DIN can be appointed as a director. While most foreign nationals (there are exceptions) are eligible to be appointed as directors, to become a managing director or full-time director, they must qualify as a resident (living in India for at least 12 months prior to appointment)./Often, investors (VCs, PEs) appoint a representative or nominee on the board of investee companies.

elements.name: Board Observer
elements.summary: Financial investors sometimes appoint an observer on the board of an investee company. An observer has the right to receive all notices, documents, and information provided to other Board members and be entitled to attend and speak at all meetings of the Board or committees./However, the observer cannot be considered for quorum and cannot vote on any resolution proposed.

elements.name: DIN
elements.summary: DIN is the director identification number. It is a unique 8-digit number issued by the Ministry of Company Affairs (MCA) to an individual who is appointed as a director of a company./DIN can be issued to individuals at the time of incorporation or separately. A maximum of three directors can apply for DIN at the time of a company’s incorporation./DIN  is typically mentioned on all documents that the individual then signs or attests as director. Once obtained, it is valid permanently, unless cancelled./DIN is unique to the individual, hence, regardless of the company on whose board the individual is a director and irrespective of how many directorships the individual holds, DIN will remain the same.

elements.name: BM
elements.summary: A meeting of the board of directors of a company. According to law, the board must meet at least once every quarter./A written notice must be sent to board members, along with an agenda specifying the details of matters that will be discussed./Board members can meet in person or via video conference./Matters usually discussed at board meetings include the company’s performance, ideas for improving productivity and growth, diversification of business, strategic decisions about new projects or activities, financing, and budgets.

elements.name: Notice
elements.appearance: colorless gas, occasionally glows green or red in discharge tubes
elements.summary: A formal written document notifying the recipient about an event or meeting. Notices can be sent for various reasons – convening board or shareholders’ meetings, intention to sell shares or exercise certain rights./Notices can be delivered by hand, speed post, or via electronic means, as mandated by the articles of association of a company./Minimum notice periods are mandated by law or articles of association.

elements.name: Short Notice
elements.summary: Shareholders in a company must be notified of a meeting at least 21 days in advance. If the management wants to hold the meeting earlier, then at least 95% of eligible shareholders must give their written consent. Consent by electronic means is acceptable./The company’s articles of association may provide for a shorter notice period (less than 21 days) for convening a general meeting.

elements.name: e-token
elements.summary: E-token contains a digital signature, which is the electronic equivalent of a physical (wet-ink) signature. A digital signature can be used to sign any document or transaction electronically. A valid digital certificate is needed to create a digital signature.

elements.name: Angel Tax
elements.summary: Angel tax is tax charged on private companies when they raise capital by issuing shares to resident investors at a price higher than the face value and fair market value of the shares./Section 56(2)(viib) of the Income Tax Act, which levies this tax, was introduced to prevent a form of money laundering by taxing private companies that were issuing shares at an excessive premium (over and above the fair market value) as a means of accounting for money that was previously unaccounted on their books./Start-up companies often raise funds from angel investors at a high premium, so does every start-up that raises capital have to pay this tax? No, not all, because start-ups registered with the Department for Promotion of Industry and Internal Trade (DPIIT) are exempt from paying angel tax.

elements.name: DPIIT
elements.summary: The Department for Promotion of Industry and Internal Trade (DPIIT) is a department under the Ministry of Commerce and Industry of the Government of India./It assists the central government in its effort to build a strong startup ecosystem and in formulating various policies relating to foreign direct investment (FDI), intellectual property rights, and so on./Eligibility criteria include:/a. Incorporated less than 10 years ago/b. Annual turnover of <INR 100 crores/c. Scalable business model/d. Activities promoting country’s economic growth/Start-ups recognised by the DPIIT enjoy various benefits, such as:/a. Tax holidays: angel tax exemption under Section 56(2)(vii)(b), payment of income tax under Section 80IAC, tax on long term capital gain under section 54(GB)/b. Self-certified declaration under six labour laws and three environmental laws confirming their compliance/c. Registration under the applicable intellectual property statutes/d. Networking and infrastructure facilities
elements.symbol: Department for Promotion of Industry and Internal Trade

elements.name: FDI
elements.summary: FDI means ‘foreign direct investment’./Typically, it refers to an individual or entity located outside India making an investment of capital into an Indian entity, usually in exchange for securities representing part ownership of the entity./Under Indian law, FDI can be under the automatic route or approval route./a. Under the automatic route, an Indian entity undertaking business activities in certain sectors can receive foreign investment without any prior approval of the government of India. In most sectors, FDI is permitted under the automatic route./b.                                       Under the approval route, an Indian entity undertaking business activities in certain sectors can receive foreign investment only after taking prior approval or permission for the transaction from the Indian government. This is necessary only in a few sectors, and the government also prescribes a limit on foreign ownership./In either case, the entity receiving the investment should furnish details of the foreign investment to the RBI or the central government through a designated authorised dealer bank.

elements.name: FEMA
elements.summary: FEMA is a government body that regulates the foreign transactions in India. It mainly regulates the foreign exchange reserves and the inflow and outflow of investments between countries.

elements.name: RTA
elements.summary: To dematerialise its shares, a company must pass a board resolution to convert its physical securities to demat. For this purpose, it must appoint a registrar and transfer agent (RTA) who will act as an intermediary to record and maintain transactions of the investors in the demat form./In case of secondary transactions of shares held in demat form, the RTA must get a confirmation from the company before approving the transfer. After this, the RTA can register the transfer in demat mode.

elements.name: FC-GPR
elements.summary: Every Indian company issuing securities to foreign investors must inform the Reserve Bank of India about it. Details of the transaction must be submitted by filing Form FC-GPR.

elements.name: FC-TRS
elements.summary: Transfer of shares to non-resident individuals or entities, and foreign investors must be reported to the Reserve Bank of India in Form FC-TRS. Details of the transaction must be submitted within 60 days from the date of the transfer./Details include:/a.Type of security transferred/b.Number of equity shares on a fully diluted basis/c.Face value of the security./d.Transfer price or sale consideration amount/e.Mode of payment/f.Name of the authorised dealer/e.Tranche details

elements.name: Share Certificate
elements.summary: Share certificates are documents that constitute proof of shareholding in a company. They are issued in the name of the shareholder, and signed by at least two directors of the company. The company seal is affixed to the certificate./A share certificate is also a document of title and hence can be pledged./Under the law, the company must pay the prescribed stamp duty on the value of shares mentioned on the certificate.

elements.name: MGT-1
elements.appearance: silvery white, tarnishing to dark gray in air
elements.summary: Form MGT-1 is a register recording details of all members holding shares in a company from the time of its incorporation./All companies (limited by shares) must maintain this register./Separate registers must be maintained for holders of equity and preference shares.

elements.name: MGT-2
elements.summary: Form MGT-2 is the register that every company must maintain to record details of holders of debentures and other securities (other than equity shares).

elements.name: PAS-3
elements.appearance: silvery metallic, glows purple in the dark
elements.summary: Form PAS-3 is a form filed with the Registrar of Companies (ROC) with details of all new allotments of shares (or other securities) at the end of each round of financing./Details mentioned in the form are:/a. List of allottees/b. Names and addresses of shareholders/c. Number of shares allotted/d. Amount paid towards the shares

elements.name: MGT-14
elements.summary: On each occasion that a company passes a resolution in its board or shareholders’ meeting, it must inform the Registrar of Companies (ROC) using Form MGT-14./All resolutions, whether relating to issue of shares, employees’ stock options, buyback of shares, amending the company’s articles of association, or change to its registered office, must be filed with ROC.

elements.name: MGT-7
elements.summary: Form MGT-7 is used for filing a company’s annual return. The annual return must be filed electronically with the Registrar of Companies (ROC) by all companies.

elements.name: AOC-4
elements.summary: AOC-4 is the form through which the financial statements and the directors’ report of a company are filed with the Registrar of Companies (ROC) annually.

elements.name: E-token
elements.summary: E-token contains a digital signature, which is the electronic equivalent of a physical (wet-ink) signature. A digital signature can be used to sign any document or transaction electronically. A valid digital certificate is needed to create a digital signature.

elements.name: DIR-12
elements.summary: Every company must file Form DIR-12 with information about its directors and other key managerial personnel to the Registrar of Companies (ROC)./Form DIR-12 must be filed within 30 days of the date of appointment or resignation of directors.

elements.name: PAS-5
elements.summary: Form PAS-5 is the complete record of shares issued by private placement to be maintained by a company./Issue of shares or convertible securities to a specific group of people is called private placement. Under private placement, the offer letter for subscription (in Form PAS-4) is sent to a maximum of 50 selected individuals (excluding the company’s employees) and qualified institutional buyers./The company must allot shares to individuals who have accepted the offer of private placement within 60 days of receiving the subscription amount from them. The subscription funds must be credited into a separate bank account opened and maintained exclusively for this purpose.

elements.name: SH-6
elements.summary: It is a register of employee stock options./Details of all stock options granted, vested, and exercised must be recorded and maintained by a company in Form SH-6.

elements.name: SH-7
elements.summary: If there is an alteration in a company’s share capital, then it must be notified to the Registrar of Companies (ROC) by filing Form SH-7./Alterations could involve :/a. Increase in the company’s authorised share capital/b. Consolidation of shares/c. Division of share capital/d. Cancellation of issue of shares
